seo.metaTitle: NWA Daily - A daily newsletter about all things Northwest Arkansas
seo.metaDescription: NWA Daily is a daily email newsletter that keeps readers up to date on the latest Northwest Arkansas news or NWA news in events, restaurants, business,  the community, politics, art, entertainment, culture, and sports in Northwest Arkansas including news about Bentonville, Rogers, Springdale, and Fayetteville

posts.title: Fayetteville's Historic Ice House Sells Units For $1.47m
posts.content:
Three commercial units in Downtown Fayetteville's historic Ice House building have been purchased for $1.47m.

  • Fresh beets: The new owner, Dylan Maisel of New Orleans, plans to use the space to open a Northwest Arkansas location of his health restaurant and smoothie shop, The Daily Beet.
  • Welcome to the neighborhood: The Ice House, located at 339 N West Ave right off Dickson St, is a mixed-use building and home to Ice House Tattoo, In Motion Boutique, and several residential units.

Read about this development and more from Talk Business & Politics HERE.

posts.title: Your Guide To The Ultimate Northwest Arkansas Valentine's Date
posts.content:
Valentine's Day is right around the corner, and we're here to help you be prepared! Check out our guide to Date Night Spots Around NWA and set up a reservation for you and your special someone.

  • Comfy: If you're keeping it cool this Valentine's, some of our favorite options that feel upscale yet casual are MJ Pizzeria, Local Lime, and Louise at Thaden Field.
  • Classy: Want to put on the ritz and hit the town in style? Make a reservation at one of these fancy establishments: Atlas, The Preacher's Son, or the Heirloom at 1907.

Find descriptions of these spots and more in our guide HERE.

posts.title: Crystal Bridges Announces Exhibitions Coming In 2023
posts.content:
From Diego Rivera to Annie Leibovitz, the 2023 Exhibition lineup at Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art will feature some of the most iconic artists of the twentieth and twenty-first centuries.

  • A lasting vision: Deigo Rivera's America brings together over 150 of Rivera's art pieces, examining the social and cultural life of Mexico and America from the 1920s to the 1940s, in the first major exhibition focused exclusively on the Mexican artist in over 20 years.
  • Say cheese: One of the most accomplished photographers of the last fifty years, Annie Leibovitz has highlighted society in publications like The Rolling Stone, Vanity Fair, and Vogue. Annie Leibovitz: Portraits explores American identities, human relationships, current events, and more through her thoughtful photography.

Find these exhibitions and more in the 2023 lineup HERE.

posts.title: Freedom's Path Hits Theaters This February
posts.content:
Produced by Fayettevlle-based Rockhill Studios, the civil-war era story Freedom's Path will debut on Feb 3, showing locally at AMC Fiesta Square in Fayetteville.

  • The plot: According to Screenrant, the story follows the Union soldier William, who intentionally injures himself and deserts battle to avoid death but gets caught up in the crossfires of Confederates hunting a group of Black fighters. 
  • Hey, I've been there: The movie was primarily filmed in the fall of 2019 at multiple Northwest Arkansas locations like Prairie Grove Battlefield Park, War Eagle Mill, Lincoln, Cane Hill, and more.

Watch the movie trailer HERE, and book tickets HERE.

posts.title: Elle King Joins The Lineup Of FreshGrass | Bentonville
posts.content:
Multi-platinum artist Elle King has been added to the lineup for FreshGrass | Bentonville, joining the outstanding bluegrass and roots artists coming to Bentonville on May 19-20.

  • Music connects: Alongside bands like Caamp, Mavis Staples, and Sierra Ferrell, the festival will also include FreshSongs, first-time music performances created by international songwriters at The House of Songs exclusively for the festival.
  • Movies and more: Beyond the music, the family-friendly festival will offer activities, local food and drink, local vendors, food and beverages, and a viewing of FreshScores, a silent film featuring original live music.

Read more about the upcoming festival HERE.

posts.title: ICYMI: Become a Fan of NWA Daily
posts.content:
Hey friends, we wanted to share a little update about NWA Daily! We've come a long way since we began in early 2021, from just an idea to over 23,000 subscribers. We've had a blast curating content and keeping you up-to-date and connected in NWA, and we are so thankful for all of you!

  • In the beginning: A little bit about us. We're just two couples that love NWA and want others to know and love it like we do! We have been running NWA Daily on the side and bootstrapping it with our own resources since the very beginning.
  • What's next: In an effort to continue to provide you with the best and most relevant content in a fun and efficient way, we're expanding our team, aiming to bring on a new full-time hire in the next few months! In conjunction with this, we're launching a reader revenue program where you can become a 'Fan' of NWA Daily through voluntary financial contributions to help us achieve goals like hiring new full-time team members!

In addition to helping us bring you better content, becoming a fan will also give you access to exclusive giveaways from our local partners. If you've enjoyed following along and have learned something new about NWA from us, we hope that you consider supporting us HERE.

posts.title: Northwest Arkansas Ranked 4th Best Places To Buy A Home In 2023
posts.content:
The Northwest Arkansas metro area was ranked the 4th best place to buy a home in 2023 by the National Association of Realtors.

  • Rapid growth: The population of Northwest Arkansas is growing at an annual rate of 2% compared to the national average of just .01%.
  • Better prices: The region ranked 2nd on the list regarding housing affordability with a median home price of $328,400 compared to the 2022 national median of $379,100.

Watch the KNWA news story HERE.

posts.title: Hugo's Of Fayetteville Nominated For Arkansas Food Hall Of Fame
posts.content:
Fayetteville's vibiest burger joint has been nominated for the 2023 class of the Arkansas Food Hall of Fame.

  • Basement burger: Located in the basement at 25 1/2 N Block Ave, Hugo's has been serving up a delicious menu since 1977, but their specialty is a top-class burger paired with homemade fries.
  • Best in state: Arkansas Heritage began the Arkansas Food Hall of Fame in 2016 to honor the great food traditions of Arkansas and the people who make them. Hugo's was the only restaurant nominated out of Northwest Arkansas this year.

See a complete list of finalists in About You HERE.

posts.title: Get Ready for Loma's Grand Opening Tomorrow
posts.content:
It's time - Loma, launched by one of the owners of Tula in Fayetteville, officially opens tomorrow! We had a chance to get a sneak peek and dine at the restaurant last week, and we just couldn't wait to tell you about it.

  • A feast for the eyes: The stunning 9,000 sqft restaurant was designed by a Mexico City architecture firm and gives off the perfect warm and cozy vibes. And, when NWA isn't blanketed in snow or ice, there is an enormous rooftop patio to enjoy. Located in the ONE Uptown building, the location is prime and is another A+ addition to the Pinnacle Hills area.
  • A taste of Mexico: In addition to some of the classics we've come to know and love at Tula like the Guacamole and the Cochinita Pibil, we also tried some delicious plates exclusive to Loma. The Pork Belly Carnitas and and Chicharron De Ribeye were fantastic, savory starters. We finished the meal with Ahi Tuna which was incredibly fresh and flavorful and the Barbacoa, which was fall-off-the-bone tender and packed with flavor.

Go ahead and start making your reservations and see for yourself why the NWA Daily crew is already planning our return.

posts.title: NWA Food Bank Takes A Stand Against Hunger
posts.content:
The Northwest Arkansas Food Bank is making a difference in the fight against hunger. In 2021, they distributed over 14m lbs of food and currently have over 110 partner agencies across Benton, Carroll, Madison, and Washington counties.

  • The rent eats first: Housing affordability directly impacts food insecurity. NWA Food Bank and organizations like Hark at Excellerate Foundation are exploring ways to help our community grow strategically, so we don't leave our most vulnerable neighbors hungry.
  • Good work: Many volunteer opportunities are available at the Food Bank, such as serving in the warehouse, volunteering at a mobile food pantry, or working in the Food Bank's garden.

Learn more about the NWA Food Bank HERE.
posts.topic: Sponsored by Hark at Excellerate Foundation

posts.title: Northwest Arkansas Tourism Nominated For Multiple Awards
posts.content:
Multiple attractions and groups from Northwest Arkansas have been nominated for Henry Awards, statewide awards given to those who have made significant contributions to the state's tourism industry.

  • Places of innovation: The Railyard Park & Butterfield Stage of Rogers and Experience Fayetteville's ArtCourt have both been nominated for The Natural State Tourism Development Award for creatively increasing community engagement. 
  • People of interest: Experience Fayetteville has been nominated for the Tourism Organization of the Year, and Luke Wiggins of Visit Rogers has been selected as a Rising Star for demonstrating leadership and commitment to the state's tourism industry.

Read more on the story HERE.

posts.title: Let Off Some Steam At The NWA Smash Lab
posts.content:
Ever wanted to take a baseball bat to your computer when the internet's slow? Hypothetically speaking, of course... However, at NWA Smash Lab, you can literally smash away your stress in a safer, more controlled environment.

  • Choose your weapon: Select your tool from the Weapon Wall, including sledgehammers, golf clubs, bats, and more, and swing away at bottles, glass plates, or old electronics. Make it a Premium session for access to BB gun shooting or glass bottle bowling!
  • Bonding by breaking: Reservations can be made for individuals or groups, and packages are available for corporate events looking for a fun way to do some team building.

Learn more and book a smash session HERE.

posts.title: $240m Of NWA's Medicare Expenses Spent Outside Of Region
posts.content:
According to the Arkansas Center for Health Improvement's analysis of Northwest Arkansas in 2019, nearly $240m of the $1.1b spent on Medicare enrollee's healthcare went towards services provided outside of the region.

  • Finding specialists: Considering cardiology procedures performed on Medicare-enrolled residents, 11% sought care outside of Northwest Arkansas. Specifically, 14% of coronary artery bypass grafting surgeries and 20% of heart valve replacement surgeries occurred outside the region.
  • Keeping pace: These findings raise concerns about the supply and demand for healthcare providers in Northwest Arkansas. As the population grows, our health sector has a unique opportunity to expand and innovate.

Listen to KUAF for more of the story HERE.

posts.title: Adventure Racing World Series Finds A New Home In NWA
posts.content:
The Adventure Racing World Series has been purchased from the Australian-based Geocentric Outdoors by current CEO Heidi Muller, who plans to move the organization's headquarters to Bentonville.

  • Extreme sports: Adventure races combine disciplines like trekking, rock climbing, paddling, mountain biking, and orienteering as teams traverse huge distances over days-long races—a perfect sport for the rugged Ozarks.
  • Natural State: Three private investors from NWA aided the purchase, two of which, Jason Wilford and Philip Sigsworth, are board members of Ozark Outdoor Foundation, which hosts Expedition Ozark, a 5-day, 390mi adventure race including biking, trekking, and paddling.

Read the full story from Arkansas Outdoors HERE.

posts.title: House Show Music Festival Coming To Bentonville This April
posts.content:
Music and hospitality will collide during City Sessions' 4th annual Home Sweet Home Music Festival in Downtown Bentonville on April 28-29.

  • In the house: This music-filled weekend will consist of 50 shows featuring 23 local artists and ten national artists hosted across 14 homes in Downtown Bentonville. Some exciting headliners include David Ramirez, Joshua James, Stephen Day, and Ira Wolf.
  • Come on in: Day passes are $60, which includes three shows plus the headliner and refreshments, or pick up a Weekend Pass, a $120 value, for just $100 when you use the discount code HSH23. If you're a superfan, the $250 Wheelhouse VIP pass includes a private show with Ira Wolf and Will Gunselman catered by Conifer at the Howard.

Find more information and reserve your tickets HERE.

posts.title: Weekend Roundup
posts.content:
After a long week of heavy snow and power outages, we wish you all a fun and relaxing weekend in Northwest Arkansas. You've earned it!

  • Peak health: The 2023 NWA Health Summit is today, Jan 27, from 9a-4p at the Jones Center in Springdale. See this schedule for a list of sessions and speakers.
  • Got lunch? Bentonville friends, head over to the grand opening of The Beach BBQ at 1080 SE 14th St today at 11:30a, and let us know what you think of NWA's newest barbecue joint!
  • Taking the stage: Head to TheatreSquared for the opening night of Kim's Convenience tonight, Jan 27, at 7:30p, or catch one of the showings on Saturday or the Sunday matinee.
  • Stick the landing: Help the Arkansas gymnastics team "Stripe the Barn" as they take on No. 8 LSU tonight, Jan 27, at 7:45p in Barnhill Arena.
  • Caffriends: Take your friends out for coffee and great conversation during the Fayetteville Coffee Crawl beginning today, Jan 27, and lasting through next week!
  • 90's kids: Reminisce over the '90s at George's Majestic Lounge in Fayetteville during a Gin & Juice: A Tribute to 90's Hip Hop this Saturday, Jan 28, at 9p.

We'll see you back here next week! Have a great Friday.

posts.title: New Exhibition On Display At Crystal Bridges
posts.content:
This weekend, Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art will open a free exhibition featuring selections from the Alfred Stieglitz Collection entitled Seeing One Another. The exhibit will be displayed in the Modern Art Gallery from Jan 28 until the end of the year.

  • Perspectives: Seeing One Another highlights multiple insights into how works of art connect individuals, groups, and ideas across time, embodying stories that can be understood in varying ways depending on the viewer.
  • Global story: Co-owned by Crystal Bridges and Fisk University, the Alfred Stieglitz Collection includes works by African, European, and American artists exploring themes of portraiture, family, and legacy.

Find more information and plan your visit HERE.

posts.title: Chef Rafael Rios Of Yeyo's Named A James Beard Best Chef Semifinalist
posts.content:
Continuing to make the headlines as one of Northwest Arkansas's most well-respected chefs, Chef Rafael Rios of Yeyo's has been announced as a James Beard Awards semifinalist in the Best Chef: South category.

  • Prestige: The James Beard Foundation has been calling attention to extraordinary people behind America's food culture for over 30 years. Winners will be celebrated at the James Beard Restaurant and Chef Awards Ceremony on June 5 at the Lyric Opera in Chicago. We're cheering on Chef Rafael as he represents NWA!
  • Andale: Yeyo's El Alma de Mexico began in 2012 out of a bright yellow food truck and has since grown into a thriving, multi-location establishment, including the Restaurant in Bentonville, the Mezcaleria y Taqueria in Downtown Rogers, the Yellow Foodtruck at the Bentonville Square, and the Blue Foodtruck at Natural State Beer Co.

Follow Yeyo's on Instagram to stay updated HERE.

posts.title: Conversate And Caffeinate During The Fayetteville Coffee Crawl

posts.title: With Incredible Sushi, Fresh Seafood, and Creative Dishes, Blu Rogers is a Must Try
posts.content:
Located in a place that is likely familiar to longtime Rogers residents, Blu Rogers recently opened in Downtown Rogers in the old City Hall building.

  • Top chef: A sister restaurant to Blu in Bentonville, Blu Rogers prides itself on having the highest quality and purest tasting fish and seafood. Familiar with the concept, we checked out this location for the first time last week for lunch!
  • Served up: We went with the Blu specials - udon soup, seasoned shishito peppers, ahi tuna salad, and the fiery whipple roll. While there are plenty of great options for dinner at Blu DTR, this was the perfect combo for our lunch there.

If you like seafood, Blu Rogers should definitely be on your list, because they do it right! Learn more about Blu Rogers HERE.

posts.title: Let Me Take A Selfie During The First Ever SNAPS NWA
posts.content:
Immerse yourself in local art and capture a one-of-a-kind selfie during the first-ever SNAPS Selfie Pop-Up event hosted by Brick & Mortar and Arli Media in Downtown Rogers at 120 W Walnut St.

  • In focus: Interact with the creations of five regional artists, photographing yourself and your friends in each of the unique "snap spots" based on February's theme: All You Need Is Love.
  • Set a time: Join the VIP Night on Thursday, Feb 2, including a meet and greet with the artists, appetizers by The Sous Chef, drinks, and more. General admission will be available Friday, Feb 3, through Sunday, Feb 5.

Reserve a session for yourself or an entire group HERE.

posts.title: University Of Arkansas Ranks High For Online Programs
posts.content:
The University of Arkansas ranked No. 35 overall for online bachelor's programs in U.S. News & World Report's 2023 list of "Best Online Programs."

  • Best in the biz: The Walton College of Business ranked No. 12 nationally in the subcategory for Online Bachelor's in Business programs.
  • Make it a master's: The state's flagship university also ranked well for multiple master's degree programs, coming in at No. 42 in Engineering, No. 74 in Education, and No. 122 in Nursing.

Read more about the U of A's online degree programs HERE.

posts.title: Executive Order Leads To Creation Of State Council For Outdoor Recreation
posts.content:
One of the latest executive orders by Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders will establish the Natural State Initiative and Natural State Advisory Council to promote outdoor recreation and increase public health and tourism.

  • All natural: In 2021, outdoor recreation generated $3.5b and 40,000 jobs for the state. This order aims to leverage that momentum to establish Arkansas as a leader in the outdoor economy.
  • Pacesetters: Northwest Arkansas has been a leading region for the state in developing outdoor recreation opportunities thanks to initiatives by groups like the NWA Council, Walton Family Foundation, and the NWA Regional Planning Commission.

Read more on the story HERE.

node.headline: The Best Spot For A Selfie In NWA

node.content:
Heirloom at the 1907 is a hidden gem located in the heart of Downtown Rogers. Tucked away in the Onyx Headquarters, this restaurant is a true oasis for foodies and those seeking a unique dining experience. From the moment you make your reservation, you know you're in for something special.

The atmosphere of Heirloom is truly one-of-a-kind. Danielle Ribuado and her team have mastered the art of hospitality, making sure that every single detail is taken care of. From the playlist in the background, to the personalized service, they have created an environment where you can truly relax and enjoy your meal.

But the real star of the show is the food. Chef Jason Paul has created a rotating prix fixe menu that takes you on a culinary journey. Every 4-6 weeks, the menu changes, giving diners the opportunity to experience something new and exciting with each visit. The restaurant seats only 20 people and is open for reservations only 3-4 nights a week. This ensures that each patron receives the highest quality experience possible.

Reservations for Heirloom drop on the 15th of each month, and they book up quickly. If you're unable to secure a reservation, you can always join the waitlist. But trust me, the wait is well worth it.

As soon as you step through the doors of Heirloom, you're transported to a different world. The atmosphere is intimate and cozy, with a warm and inviting ambiance. The staff is attentive and friendly, making sure that you have everything you need to enjoy your meal.

The food is absolutely outstanding. Chef Jason Paul has created a menu that is both innovative and delicious. The flavors are bold and complex, and the presentation is beautiful. Each course is thoughtfully curated, and the progression of flavors is expertly executed.

The prix fixe menu changes every 4-6 weeks, which means that each visit is a new and exciting experience. You never know what culinary creations will be on the menu, but you can be sure that they will be delicious. The variety of flavors and textures is truly amazing, and it's a pleasure to see how Chef Jason Paul is able to take simple ingredients and elevate them to a new level.

The restaurant seats only 20 people, which means that it's an intimate and cozy dining experience. The small size of the restaurant also ensures that each patron receives the highest quality experience possible. The service is personalized and attentive, and the staff is always happy to answer any questions you may have.

In conclusion, Heirloom at the 1907 is a hidden gem that is not to be missed. The atmosphere, the food, and the service are all outstanding, and it's a pleasure to dine in such a unique and special place. If you're looking for a truly memorable dining experience, make sure to book a reservation at Heirloom.
node.title: Unforgettable Dining at Heirloom at the 1907: A Hidden Gem in Downtown Rogers, Arkansas

node.content:
Northwest Arkansas is leading the state in many ways with its active plans for clean energy, its elevating tech scene, its strong foothold in advanced air mobility, and its mountain biking infrastructure. Among the array of reasons NWA is a great place to be, the region is also making moves to be known for its approach to holistic health. 

Photo courtesy of Andrea Piacquadio

Already, institutions like the University of Health and Performance, the Children's Safety Center, and the Whole Health Institute create environments where the priority and emphasis are on the health of the whole person. The region's latest endeavor to make NWA an epicenter of holistic health is the Alice L. Walton School of Medicine, which is working to combine conventional medicine with integrative techniques and principles. Emotional and mental health is top of mind right now for many people and is an essential part of the well-rounded nature of a healthy community. 

Photo courtesy of Tirachard Kumtanom

While new initiatives are happening, there are already several organizations in NWA for counseling and therapy of all kinds. One of the hardest things sometimes, we think, is how many options there are. So the team at NWA Daily has done some research to narrow down 13 counseling options in the region to create a resource for your mental and emotional health journey.

Photo courtesy of Alex Green

In order by location:

1. Psychology and Counseling Associates

1 W. Sunbridge Dr., Fayetteville

5434 W Walsh Ln., Rogers

Psychology and Counseling Associates has been voted Best Mental Health Clinic for 10 years in a row. It has an office in Fayetteville and Rogers and offers services for ADHD/Learning Difficulties, Alcohol Use Disorder, Anxiety, Depression, Marital Therapy, PTSD, Sexual Health, Eating Disorders, and more. 

Fayetteville: 479.443.5575

Rogers: 479.442.2311

2. Talk Center Counseling Services

130 N College Ave, Fayetteville

Talk Center Counseling strives to help people find their sense of wholeness. Their licensed professional counselors and social service workers serve adults, families, teens, and children. Talk Center Counseling also offers group therapy for teenage girls and a yoga group for those suffering from anxiety.

479.396.8806

3. The Joshua Center

3680 N. Investment Dr, Fayetteville

2105 S. 54th St, Rogers

920 S. Caroline St, Siloam Springs

The Joshua Center offers individual adult therapy, therapy for children, adolescents, and families, couples therapy, pre-marital counseling, and discernment work. The center utilizes different approaches such as emotionally-focused therapy, play therapy, EMDR, brain spotting, and others. 

Fayetteville: 479.435.9356

Rogers: 479.268.4557

Siloam Springs: 479.373.2377

4. Midtown Counseling

1845 Green Acres Rd, Fayetteville

 Midtown Counseling provides counseling services and specialized evaluations to individuals, families, and groups. They accept most major insurance providers and are certified by the Arkansas Board of Examiners in Counseling, the National Board of Certified Counselors, and the American Counseling Association.

479.957.8546

Photo courtesy of cottonbro

5. Pinnacle Counseling 

5500 W Pinnacle Pointe Dr, Rogers

Pinnacle Counseling has been serving the Rogers area for 15 plus years with client-centered approaches to anxiety, depression, marriage and family counseling, etc. Pinnacle Counseling counselors help their clients find empowerment and clarity to achieve their wellness goals. 

479.282.2443

6. Oaks Counseling

6815 Isaac's Orchard Rd, Springdale

Oaks Counseling is a group of trained and certified counselors with decades of combined experience who are fully equipped to help you process whatever it is you need to move toward a healthier life. 

7. Professional Counseling Services of NWA

6801 Isaac's Orchard Rd, Springdale

Professional Counseling Services of NWA specialize in individual counseling, stress management, clinical hypnosis, and professional life coaching. At Professional Counseling Services of NWA, you are the expert of your own life, collaborating with an expert in counseling to find solution-focused, individualized goals and treatments for your issues. 

479.799.5577

8. Brookway Counseling

801 Carlton St, Springdale

Brookway Counseling has a team of qualified and experienced counselors specializing in depression and anxiety counseling, ADHD, EMDR therapy, Christian counseling, psychological testing, eating disorders, marriage and family counseling, and online teletherapy.

479.255.5414

9. NWA Premier Therapy

2103 S 54th St, Rogers

NWA Premier Therapy specializes in trauma-focused counseling, though they also offer play therapy, therapy for those struggling with HSP issues, therapy for LGBTQIA+ individuals, grief counseling, and much more.

479.372.7446

479.389.8188 (text)

Photo courtesy of SHVETS

10. Fresh Roots Counseling

3901 W Financial Pkwy, Rogers

Fresh Roots Family Counseling has been serving the NWA community since 1995. They have a team of 20+ licensed professional counselors specializing in many therapy areas. Some techniques that make Fresh Roots stand out are Emotion-Focused couples therapy, EMDR, play therapy, co-parenting counseling, and Sexual Addiction Therapy.

479.986.8655

11. Bentonville Counseling Collective

2104 SE 14th St, Bentonville

Bentonville Counseling Collective offers counseling services to all those wanting to make a positive change in their lives. They specialize in relationship counseling, gender transition counseling, expressive arts therapy, therapy for therapists, telehealth video counseling, and trauma-informed therapy.

479.310.6850

12. Creative Counseling Center

902 McClain Rd, Bentonville

The counselors of the Creative Counseling Center of NWA have created a space of casual, confidential, and collaborative conversation to aid you on your healing journey. They offer services to individuals and couples for a wide variety of issues. 

479.364.0075

13. Soul Talk Therapy

900 SE 5th St, Bentonville

Soul Talk Therapy is in a quaint, comfortable space with dedicated counselors cultivating safe environments to explore thoughts, feelings, and experiences without any threat of judgment. 

479.888.5546

Photo courtesy of Alex Green

If you're still looking to find free and affordable counseling near you, or you want to learn more about what is available, check out opencounseling.com. For tips on how to find a counselor fit for you in NWA, read this blog post from Fresh Roots Family Counseling.

node.content:
There are very few people on the planet who do not stop and acknowledge an aircraft that passes by overhead. Even if it’s as brief a moment as one second, people notice and almost ubiquitously harbor some fascination with flying objects in the sky. 

Photo courtesy of Carol Zoch

It seems like such a distant place — the sky — but it really is more approachable than people realize. The Wright Brothers saw to that with their first flight in 1903. Aviation has come such a long way in just over a century, as now, flying is something anyone can do with training and help from local flight schools. 

Northwest Arkansas is slowly becoming one of the hottest spots for aviation in the United States – specifically recreational aviation, because of its accessibility and the ideal environment that this part of the country provides. Recreational aviation, or backcountry aviation, has put NWA and the Ozarks on the map for many pilots, almost exclusively due to the initiative at Fly Oz, the region’s recreational aviation arm based in Bentonville. 

Photo courtesy of Fly Oz 

Fly Oz and aviation enthusiasts in this part of the country have worked with private land owners to connect pilots and non-pilots to activities and experiences through a network of grass airstrips on land otherwise unreachable. Director of Fly Oz, Chip Gibbons, said people who come to fly in NWA have a bigger picture of the region than those who come mountain bike in the area for a week, which makes sense. Through initiatives to get people in the air and to different parts of the region and state, NWA has become a base in a network of adventure. 

“Here, our focus has really been on what you do once you have arrived,” Gibbons said. “Get out of the airplane, take in the scenery, do some fishing, do some paddling, you know, whatever lights you up.” 

Flying in and out of the backcountry is what the region is primarily known for in the world of aviation, but it also has the ideal infrastructure for learning to fly at any level and in any air space. Due to the lower density altitude here allowing airplanes to perform better, and the local flight schools being some of the most resourceful and approachable around, there aren’t many places better than NWA to learn to fly for fun.

“It’s almost the perfect little environment to do this in,” Gibbons said. “I don’t know what I would change about where we live that would make it better.” 

The two leading flight schools in the area are Summit Aviation in Bentonville and ARH Aviation in Springdale. Summit Aviation is the fixed-based operator at Thaden Field, a municipal and private jet airport in downtown Bentonville. ARH Aviation is a premier aviation supplier located at the Springdale municipal general aviation airport. Whether you train through Summit Aviation, participate in its OZ1 Flying Club department or learn to fly with experts at ARH Aviation, the sky is yours to conquer. Our region is yours to behold like never before. 

Photo courtesy of Carol Zoch

Chad Cox, the president of Summit Aviation, told Talk Business & Politics that Flying in NWA “isn’t just about getting from Point A to Point B.” It’s also about connecting to what’s happening in all the areas of recreation and leisure in NWA, adding to the overall adventure. 

Fly Oz and Fly AHR offer discovery flights and charter flights of different kinds for you to see and explore the beauty of our region in a whole new way. The scenic flights are also perfect for trying out how it feels to be in the sky. Like so many in recent years, who knows, you might immediately decide that becoming a pilot is for you. 

Becoming a private pilot through Summit Aviation in Bentonville or ARH Aviation in Springdale costs in the ballpark of $10,000 after you purchase course materials, pay for exam fees, aircraft rental, and ground and air instruction. Though it’s a bit pricey, there are scholarships out there to help. 

Whether you have a desire to become a pilot or not, there is a whole perspective of our region from the sky just waiting for you. So go check it out, and you won’t be disappointed.

The Jones Center is another one of those special amenities in Northwest Arkansas that if you don’t know about it, you should. The center is 220.000 square feet of space, deemed as a destination for growth. Bernice Jones, a driving force in the region, gifted the center to Springdale 25 years ago with the promise that “All are welcome.” 

 

The center is a recreation, education, and event center founded with a mission to strengthen and enrich the community, celebrate culture, and be a conduit for service and thriving collaboration. The vision for The Jones Center has always been that the community would be a part of it and make it their own. And with people doing just that, the center is continuously growing and adapting to the ever-changing region. 

 

The Jones Center and its 52-acre campus are currently in a phase of re-imagining. A project is brewing to “elevate The Jones Center’s core indoor recreation amenities with sustainability in mind while complimenting and blending with the Springdale Downtown Revitalization Master Plan.” 


﻿

 

Right now, the Jones Campus includes The Jones Center and the Center for Non-Profit @ the JTL Shops. The Jones Center has amenities such as an ice arena, pools, fitness center, gymnasium, runway bike park, and more. The Non-Profit @ the JTL Shops is home to more than 40 nonprofit organizations serving NWA, professional office and meeting space, and the Harvey Jones Education Building. 


 

The vision for the campus consists of bold changes that include introducing new open spaces and plazas, incorporating art pieces that pique interest and act as culturally inspired place-makers, and creating an interconnected system of hard and soft surface trails that tie The Jones Campus to downtown and beyond. The vision has a multi-layered approach with theme-based programming. The themes are wellness and recreation, gardens and ecology, community and gathering, arts and culture, and campus support. 


 

The project’s goals include creating another destination in NWA where people gather, “recreate, celebrate, and build a stronger sense of community,” expanding on Bernice’s ethos of welcoming all. The design elements of the project include the Meto Spine, Emma Ave. Connector + JTL Courtyard, The Community Common, OZ Play Area, Fitness Pad, OZ Gardens + Expanded Action Sports, and Woven Links + Patchwork Parking + JTL Plaza. 

 

Click HERE to learn all about it.
node.title: The Jones Campus: A Campus Adapting With A Continued Vision For Welcoming All

The City of Fayetteville is a world leader in the efforts of environmental sustainability, and the latest 50-acre park project downtown is no exception to the city’s goals. Construction on the Cultural Arts Corridor or, The Ramble, is currently underway with efforts to advance the city’s ecological and elemental care with sustainable means and ends, said Peter Nierengarten, the City’s Environmental Director and The Ramble’s project manager. The Ramble will be the city’s first large urban park, and though it will be similar to other parks in the U.S., The Ramble will stand out as a result of its attention to the surrounding environment. 

“It’s got a really strong focus on sustainability, low impact development, stormwater, and native ecology,” Nierengarten said. “And I think that will set it apart.”The Ramble will be the first in Arkansas to be a certified SITES project. The certification, according to The Sustainable SITES Initiative, determines that a landscape project helps “reduce water demand, filter and reduce stormwater runoff, provide wildlife habitat, reduce energy consumption, improve air quality, improve human health, and increase outdoor recreation opportunities.” 

The Ramble will check all of these boxes and more as it moves along toward completion. The new outdoor public space will not only provide spaces for native plant species and stormwater storage, but it will provide opportunities for anyone and everyone who wants to come and celebrate arts and culture or enjoy recreational activities or events. Nierengarten said, The Ramble will be a flexible space for programming that could be used for anything from small-scale events to a 2,500+ person festival. 

“The park will have space for downtown events including concerts and performances or festivals, starts and finishes for bicycle and running races, and everything in between,” Nierengarten said, “including when it’s not a programmed activity.”

The primary elements of The Ramble are the Fay Jones Woods, the Razorback Greenway, new streetscapes on West Avenue, a new parking deck on the corner of West and Dickson streets, and a new Civic Space on West Avenue. 

﻿

The improvements to the Fay Jones Woods will include the restoration of Tanglewood Branch Creek, which will be accessible to the public, providing a spot for cooling off in the hot summer months. There will also be new trails in the forest, gathering spaces, informal paths, and a boardwalk. The West Avenue Civic Plaza will feature a central lawn, promenade, art gardens, trails, and two buildings on the north and south ends that will be developed through public-private partnerships. Houses Inc. in Fayetteville has proposed one of the buildings be a four-story Food Hall. 

According to a press release, The Ramble’s name references “a full embrace of the journey” and incorporates the ideas behind the cadence of a directionless walk or bike ride, or a spontaneous conversation. The name also nods to an Arkansas-born musician and actor who hosted Midnight Ramble sessions in a barn on his property in Woodstock, New York, until his death in 2012.  

The Ramble is a project made possible by the Walton Family Foundation’s Design Excellence Program (DEP), which promotes high-level design in NWA. Nierengarten said all the DEP projects will complement each other, but The Ramble will “be an experience unlike anything else in Northwest Arkansas, from my perspective.” 

The Ramble is on track to be complete by March 2024. To see more about The Ramble and the timeline of the project, click HERE or see below.
